titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to Special Collections in the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2010

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Billy May (1916-2004) was an American arranger, composer, musician, and bandleader. The collection chiefly consists of holograph or photocopied manuscript scores, parts, lead sheets, and manuscript sketches. Additional materials include printed scores, part changes, film cues, and a handful of counterpoint exercises.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Billy May Arrangements were re-processed by Christopher Hartten in 2010. The finding aid was coded for EAD by Christopher Hartten in November 2010.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Ella Fitzgerald Collection (ML31.F58) and Charlie Barnet Collection of Big Band Arrangements (ML31.B27) contain additional Billy May manuscript scores.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The Billy May Arrangements are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Billy May Arrangements are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Billy May Arrangements, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born in Pittsburgh to Isabel Stevenson and Ed May
Arranges first work, When Yuba Plays the Rhumba on the Tuba, while at Schenley High School
Joins the Pittsburgh Local AFM and tours with the Etzi Covato band as a trombone player
Meets Charlie Barnet and begins writing arrangements for him on a weekly basis, including the hit Cherokee
Charlie Barnet hires him to play trumpet with his band on a permanent basis
Joins the Glenn Miller band and delivers his first trumpet solo on I Dreamt I Dwelt In Harlem

eventgrp.event: Writes arrangements for Frank Sinatra's Your Hit Parade and for the Phil Harris band on The Jack Benny Show
Begins career as a recording arranger/conductor

chronitem.event: Plays on the Red Skelton Show under Ozzie Nelson and works with John Scott Trotter on Bing Crosby's Kraft Music Hall
Works with Alan Livingston at Capitol Records to produce recordings for children, including the hit tune I Taut I Taw a Puddy Tat

eventgrp.event: Arranges and records almost constantly for the music and entertainment industry's biggest names, including Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald, Bing Crosby, Nat King Cole, Peggy Lee, Johnny Mercer, Mel Blanc, and Stan Freberg
Composes original soundtrack for the film Sergeants Three, as well as music for various television shows, such as The Green Hornet

chronitem.event: Abandons road touring and sells rights for the traveling Billy May Band to entrepreneur Ray Anthony
Wins Grammy Award for best arrrangement for his album Big Fat Brass
Wins Grammy Award for best arrrangement for Come Dance With Me
Produces arrangements for Time-Life documentaries The Swing Era and As You Remember Them
Dies in San Juan Capistrano, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Billy May Arrangements principally consist of holograph or photocopied manuscript scores, parts, lead sheets, and sketches for works created between 1939 and 1995. Additional materials include printed scores, part changes, film cues, and a handful of counterpoint exercises. Although May worked almost exclusively as an arranger for long periods throughout his career, he did compose original music, and several of these titles are represented in this collection. I Taut I Taw a Puddy Tat, Front Page Rag, and his film score for Sergeants Three are notable examples. Titles and cross-references are arranged alphabetically and standardized according to Jack Mirtle's The Music of Billy May: a Discography (1998). Part sets are complete unless indicated otherwise.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Billy May Arrangements
arrangement.p: The Billy May Arrangements are organized in one series:

note.p: Laid in: wind and brass part changes

did.unittitle: Do nothin' 'till you hear from me
Do you know what it means to miss New Orleans?

note.p: Laid in: optional parts and insertions

did.unittitle: I can't believe (you're in love with me)
I don't know where I'm goin' (but I'm glad you come along)
I guess I'll have to change my plans
I taut I saw a puddy tat

note.p: Arrangement by Gil Evans for the Billy May Orchestra

did.unittitle: I've got you under my skin
A kiss to build a dream on
Love is just around the corner

note.p: Final section of arrangement by Hynie Beau
Includes: "Chloe's song;" "Heard ya the first time;" "I'm back where I started;" "Once more won't hurt;" "Too soon for June"
Includes: "All of nothing at all;" "Getting sentimental;" "Without a song"
Laid in: wind and brass part changes
Laid in: film scenario cues and miscellaneous piano-vocal scores
Includes sections titled: Politely; Dat dere; Ala mode; Shout; Noodling; Half step song; Coffee
Includes section titled: Excerpts from Wozzeck (Alban Berg)
Includes sections titled: Whistler; Sally; Quartet for strings; Hope the band; Dont fence me

did.unittitle: These are the good old days

note.p: Laid in: piano-vocal score used for arrangement

did.unittitle: When I take my sugar to tea
When my sugar walks down the street
When the saints go marching in
You and the night and the music
You stepped out of a dream
You'd be so nice to come home to
